moves.1. e4: This was actually a fun game to play.  There are moments when I sweated.  Here, white opens with a king pawn opening.
moves.2. Qf3 Nf6 3. Bc4 Bc5: As you can see, he brought out his queen early in the game. White is at a disadvantage, but he has beaten me in the past by bringing out his queen early.
moves.4. c3 O-O 5. Qh3 d6 6. g4 Bxg4 7. Qh4 Qd: I did take a pawn, but I blundered here -- or you can say, I "sacrificed a piece.
moves.8... Bf3: I did take a pawn, but I blundered here -- or you can say, I "sacrificed" a piece. I wasn't going to trade my Queen for a pawn, but that wasn't in my thoughts. I wanted to trap the King and the Knight took my bishop.
moves.9. Nxf3 Nc6 10. Bf1 d5 11. exd5: Here, I deliberately sacrificed a pawn to prepare an Alekhine Gun. The idea is to open a file for the use of your rooks.
I had to keep my knight back to guard my h7 pawn.  The threat of Checkmate is very, very real.
moves.14... Rd3 15. a3 Rfd8 16. b4 Bxf2+ 17. R: Here, I've got my gun and I'm getting rid of some problem pieces.  Most notably parts of his army that hasn't been deployed.
I didn't take his rook because it would have been a distraction.
With his knight out of the way, the threat of Checkmate is somewhat stopped. So I am focusing on Checkmate myself.
moves.26... Rg2+: And this is where he resigned.  There was one place where his king could go, and I had full control of the game.
